review_title: Controlling CEO - devastating formerly positive workplace
pros: The people - although they are all leaving rapidly. 40% staff turnover when I left. The people are amazing.
cons: The leadership team - controlling, micro-managing, doesn't live up to values. Union-busting tactics and bullying.

review_title: Current management have ruined this place
pros: The most incredible group of staff committed to making things better at work and beyond work
cons: The current management seem hell-bent on destroying everything good about the organisation. Since the current CEO joined, the progressive ethos of the organisation has changed beyond recognition, and with it about 50% of staff have left. When I left the culture had become highly toxic - management through intimidation - especially w/r to the 'scorched earth' approach to rejecting unionisation.

review_title: Hard to describe how toxic things have become
pros: Staff care passionately about trying to make the organisation better - and will go out of their way to support that end.
cons: Management have lost the plot - defensive, bunker mentality has set in and there is an open war against the staff, who have successfully unionised. This comes from the top down.

review_title: A shocking breakdown of trust and goodwill
pros: The majority of staff are incredibly talented, hard-working, intelligent and kind.
cons: The senior management team works actively to intimidate unionised members of staff, the new strategy lacks any clarity of direction or planned impact, and salaries are being intentionally driven down in the context of a 40% staff turnover rate.

review_title: An organisation that does not practice what it preaches
pros: Culture of support and collaboration between colleagues. Optimistic vision to create a better world. Good benefits.
cons: The organisation has been through several rounds of poorly managed strategic reviews. Leadership is not communicating this change adequately and is actively encouraging "dissidents" to leave. It has clamped down heavily on efforts to unionise. Big vision to change the world is further constrained by lack of resource, London-centric infrastructure, and unclear goals and incentives established from the top.

review_title: Don't stay longer than a year
pros: Lovely people, nice/ supportive culture amongst all colleagues. The starting salary is pretty good for the third sector but its not a comfortable wage to live on as a junior member of staff in London.
cons: Very little upward movement or room for progression - quite natural for a small organisation. The company doesn't support or value internal promotion. From my own experience, and the experience of others, HR are there to defend senior colleagues and the organisation rather than supporting staff members.
